brief_summary.textblock:
This study was designed to evaluate urinary function before and one year after single
      incision sling placement at the time of robotic sacrocolpopexy. The thought is that the more
      minimally-invasive, single incision sling would provide a similar subjective success rates
      as those of retropubic and trans-obturator slings.

clinical_study.brief_title: Single Incision Suburethral Sling at Time of Robotic Sacrocolpopexy

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  all patients undergoing single incision sling placement at the time of robotic
             sacrocolpopexy during the study period

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  previous surgical treatment for stress urinary incontinence (SUI)

study_pop.textblock:
Our study population included all women undergoing single incision sling placement at the
        time of robotic sacrocolpopexy

clinical_study.official_title: Single Incision Suburethral Sling at Time of Robotic Sacrocolpopexy

primary_outcome.description: Subjects will undergo a cough stress test to evaluate for stress urinary incontinence.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: possible mesh related complications such as: exposure/erosion, urinary retention, voiding dysfunction, chronic pain and dyspareunia will be collected throughout the study period
This validated questionnaires will be given to subject to collect subjective data
this validated questionnaire will be completed by subject to collect subjective data
This validated questionnaire will be given to subjects to collect subjective data regarding urinary incontinence

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Cohort, Time Perspective: Prospective
